awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Automating Construction of Polarizable, Flexible, Nonreactive Force-Fields for Metal-Organic Frameworks & Applications to Helium and Solar Water Splitting Gas Purifications
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This CAREER award supports computational and theoretical research and education in predicting candidate materials for gas separation. Solar water splitting is a renewable energy source that could be used to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. In solar water splitting, sunlight energy is captured by turning water into hydrogen and oxygen gases. Hydrogen is a clean fuel that generates only water when burned. In this project, the PI and his team of student researchers will use computational modeling to predict high performance membrane materials for separating the gaseous products of solar water splitting. The PI's approach may lead to more efficient and lower cost hydrogen producing devices for energy applications.

Membrane materials will also be predicted for the application to purify helium from naturally occurring gases. Helium is traditionally purified by liquefying it at extremely cold temperatures, but enormous energy is required to cool to these temperatures. The PI's team will develop computational methods to search a recently published database of metal-organic framework materials to identify molecule sieves having pore sizes and other characteristics suitable for helium purification. They will further develop computational methods to model gas separations in membranes made from these materials. This should reduce energy requirements during helium purification, by allowing part of the gas purification to be performed at moderate temperatures. The computational methods developed in this project will be made publically available in software tools developed by the PI's group.

Educational activities are an important part of this project. The PI will train graduate and undergraduate students in computational materials science methods. Graduate students will perform doctoral dissertation research extending the capabilities of computational methods. The PI and graduate students will develop YouTube videos explaining computational materials science at levels appropriate to K to 12 and undergraduate students and the general public. They will also prepare training modules to be disseminated through Nanohub.org and that explain computational materials science techniques to graduate students and professionals. The PI and graduate students will perform outreach to middle and high school students by being science fair judges. Students from under-represented groups will be involved in the project. 

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This CAREER award supports computational and theoretical research and education in predicting candidate materials for gas separation. The PI and students will research strategies to automatically parameterize flexible, polarizable force-fields from quantum chemistry calculations. These force-fields will be used in classical molecular dynamics and Monte Carlo simulations of metal-organic frameworks to compute gas diffusion constants and adsorption isotherms. A database of experimentally known metal-organic framework crystal structures will be screened to identify metal-organic framework-based materials suitable for purifying (a) helium from naturally occurring gas sources and (b) hydrogen gas from solar water splitting. Cryogenic distillation is currently the primary helium purification method. Using helium-selective membranes instead for all or portions of this purification could dramatically reduce energy requirements. Solar water splitting is an environmentally friendly and renewable hydrogen gas source. Wireless solar water splitting uses particles immersed in liquid to cogenerate a hydrogen and oxygen gas mixture with trace water vapor. Wireless solar water splitting could offer higher gas generation rates per volume than wired solar water splitting containing distinct anode and cathode compartments. This project will enable more widespread use of wireless solar water splitting (and wired solar water splitting with small anode-cathode gap distance) by identifying suitable metal-oxide framework-based materials for hydrogen-oxygen-water gas separations. Because constructing mechanically robust membranes from pure metal-oxide framework crystals is difficult, the PI will aim to predict easier-to-fabricate mixed matrix membranes containing metal-oxide framework crystals embedded in mechanically robust polymers. 

Prior metal-oxide framework studies showed framework flexibility that sometimes impacts gas diffusion constants by orders of magnitude. The key scientific challenge is to develop computationally efficient, automated methods to construct accurate flexible force-fields. To achieve this, the PI's research team will combine (1) the Density Derived Electrostatic and Chemical method for computing net atomic charges and other atomic properties with (2) a modification of Tkatchenko-Scheffler self-consistent dispersion screening to compute polarizabilities and dispersion coefficients with (3) a modification of the quick force-field (QuickFF) method for computing flexibility parameters. By computing system-specific force-field parameters, this approach should achieve higher accuracy than generic force-fields. The computational methods developed in this project will be made publically available in software tools developed by the PI's group.

Educational activities are an important part of this project. The PI will train graduate and undergraduate students in computational materials science methods. Graduate students will perform doctoral dissertation research extending the capabilities of computational methods. The PI and graduate students will develop YouTube videos explaining computational materials science at levels appropriate to K to 12 and undergraduate students and the general public. They will also prepare training modules to be disseminated through Nanohub.org and that explain computational materials science techniques to graduate students and professionals. The PI and graduate students will perform outreach to middle and high school students by being science fair judges. Students from under-represented groups will be involved in the project.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit and Scientific Outcomes

Research carried out with funding from this award produced the following scientific outcomes.

Computational screening of a metal-organic framework database to identify structures suitable for particular gas separations. Starting with a database of approximately 5000 experimentally-derived metal-organic framework crystal structures that were pre-cleaned to remove solvent molecules, we screened for and rejected structures containing misbonded atoms. We screened for and rejected structures containing toxic, rare, or expensive chemical elements. We identified the subset of structures containing small pores that allow the small molecules hydrogen and helium to easily move through while hindering motion of larger molecules such as methane. Using quantum chemistry calculations, we optimized the geometries of these metal-organic frameworks and rejected those structures that exhibited large deformations compared to the experimental structures. We then parameterized polarizable, flexible forcefields for a small number of metal-organic frameworks that passed these screening criteria.

We developed new computational methods to parameterize polarizable, flexible forcefields. Classical forcefields are simple mathematical formulas to describe interactions between materials. In this project, forcefields were required to describe interactions between the gas molecules and the metal-organic frameworks. In this project, we improved the forcefield accuracy by including terms (called flexibility parameters) describing vibrations of the metal-organic framework atoms and by allowing the forcefield's atoms to respond to local electric fields (called a polarizable forcefield). To do this, we developed new methods that extract the following atom-in-material properties from quantum chemistry calculations: net atomic charges, bond orders, atom-in-material polarizabilities and dispersion coefficients, and Lennard-Jones parameters. We programmed these new methods to compute atom-in-material descriptors into the Chargemol software developed by us. We also developed methods that extract the following forcefield flexibility parameters from quantum chemistry calculations: bond-stretching, angle-bending, and torsion parameters. 

Classical atomistic simulations and continuum modeling to predict the performance of mixed-matrix membranes for helium/methane and hydrogen purifications. Methane is a major component of natural gas. Much of the helium supply worldwide comes from purifying it as a minor component from natural gas. Using our custom-built polarizable, flexible forcefields, we performed classical molecular dynamics and Monte Carlo simulations in the RASPA software to compute gas adsorption and diffusion properties of helium, methane, and hydrogen gases in metal-organic frameworks. We then used the Maxwell model to design mixed matrix membranes for separating helium from methane. These membranes contain metal-organic framework nanocrystals embedded in a polymer matrix. We computed membrane areas, intermediate stream compositions, and flow rates for a multi-stage membrane cascade including intermediate recycle streams that can produce a 90 mol% pure helium product stream from a natural gas feed containing 1 mol% helium.

Broader Impacts: 

During this project, 6 graduate students, one post-doc, and one undergraduate student were trained as researchers on the project. Of the graduate students who performed research on this project, 2 completed PhD degrees, 3 completed MS degrees, and 3 are currently working towards PhD degrees. (The students who completed PhD degrees first completed MS degrees.) Several of these graduate students come from under-represented groups. The post-doc completed his research internship on the project and subsequently became an assistant professor at another university. 

This project resulted in a number of significant work products, including many peer-reviewed journal articles, 12 interactive simulation modules on Nanohub.org, 10 YouTube tutorials, and an updated Chargemol program version. Most of these journal articles were published open access, which makes them freely accessible to a worldwide audience. These 12 educational modules on Nanohub.org interactively demonstrate different types of classical atomistic simulations performed using the RASPA software to compute material properties. These 10 YouTube tutorials explain how to compute key atom-in-material properties using Chargemol and other software programs (see https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCI3m7kq0UFJrW-62sRysh0Q). The Chargmol software is available online at ddec.sourceforge.net.

During this project, we participated in several volunteer outreach activities to help interest young people to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics: (a) judging for science fair and engineering design contests, (b) science demonstrations and career presentations at K-12 schools, (c) a one-day science demonstration at a science museum, and (d) career presentations and interactive engineering activities for high school students on the New Mexico State University campus.

The new computational methods developed during this project are being widely used across many scientific disciplines. The Chargemol software is currently being used by approximately 100 research groups worldwide. For example, some of our methods to compute forcefield precursors are being used by other research groups to study large biomolecules, organic liquids, and ionic liquids. Our method to compute bond orders is being used by other research groups to study many different kinds of materials including catalytic reactions. In addition to scientific research, several developments in this project will impact chemistry education. This includes bond orders and bond order components that provide a fundamental understanding of diatomic molecules and other materials.
